title: The Stickit minister,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: under the very hand which now extracted the cabbage under a galling cross fire. He observed how Humpy Joe, the pride of Simon Square, deftly removed the " lum hat" of the newest teacher, who had yet to learn what clothes to come in when he set out to instruct the youth of Gifford Park. He saw with complaisance Archie Drabble, the "de'il" of the school, prepare a hand grenade of moist mud for the superintendent,  as he thought.

title: The Stickit minister :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: But Cleg Kelly was not bashful, so he readily spoke to them. He noted, especially, a spruce party of three leaving a chemist's shop on the shortest track between the park and the meadows, and he followed them down through the narrow defile of Gifford Park —

title: The Stickit minister,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It was manifestly impossible to receive such a number of wild loons at Hunker Court. They were every one upon terms of open war with the Gifford Park train- bands ; and had a couple of them showed their faces in the neighborhood at any hour of the day or night, the " Cooee-EE " of the park would have sounded, and fists and brickbats would have been, going in a couple of shakes. Clearly, then, as they could not come to her without breaking her

title: Stickit Minister, and some common men
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: But Cleg Kelly was notbashful, so he readily spoke to them. He noted,especially, a spruce party of three leaving achemist's shop on the shortest track between thepark and the meadows, and he followed themdown through the narrow defile of Gifford Park—

title: The Stickit minister,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: a spruce party of three leaving a chemist's shop on the shortest track between the park and the meadows, and he followed them down through the narrow defile of Gifford Park thoughts of petty larceny crystallizing in his heart. Ere they could escape through the needle's eye at the further end, Cleg Kelly had accosted them after his kind.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Just then, when things were at their brightest, and Nickseemed on the high road to fortune, and had resolved to keepTowser altogether, the mother of the child unexpectedly visitedDinah at Gifford Park, and nearly went mad when she wastold that her boy was missing, and had been for weeks. " I thoucht ye didna care whether it lived or dee'd," saidDinah.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: In the end they tossed up for it, and Nick, by using hislucky penny with two heads managed to win, so Nobbs wasforced to remain in the den as nurse. When Nick reachedGifford Park he was amazed "to find no commotion whatever;nothing seemed to have happened ; no one looked distressed

title: Stickit Minister, and some common men
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.

title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: I hadforgotten, though only for a moment, the little wife working among hercloud of feathery linen and trimmings, and the little white house roundthe corner above the Meadows. You may guess whether or no I hurriedalong between ash "backets" of the most unparklike Gifford Park, howsharply I turned and scudded along Hope Park, dodging the clothes' poststo the right, from which prudent housewives had removed the ropes withthe deepening of the twilight.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Turning down the small street known as Gifford Park, Nicksoon came upon a suitable child to find in the person of alittle fellow of fifteen months, who had been playing in thegutter and making mud-pies, till he was more like a mud-idolthan a bairn. The dirt seemed to have annoyed the oldwoman who had charge of him, for she had just given him aslap or two and lest him crying, at the same time expressing awish that she might never see him again.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: All this severe exertion of brain and body had taken time,and it was now nearly dark, so Nick decided to restore Towserat once to his legal guardian. The walk to Gifford Park wasan agreeable relaxation, though he had to carry Towser,cheered as he was with the thought of being rid of such atroublesome charge. He found the stair quite easily, and,knocking at Mrs Clark's door, was charmed to find the oldwoman herself within.
